raw_text:
BBC leads interactive Bafta wins
 
 The BBC and the National Theatre have led the field at this year's Interactive Bafta awards.
 
 The National Theatre's Stagework website picked up the prize for best learning as well as top factual site. The BBC collected three awards, including best online entertainment for the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy Adventure Game. Spooks Interactive took the best interactive TV prize. The annual awards recognise the best in digital media. BBC Sport Interactive fought off competition from CBBC Newsround and the Guardian to take home the best news and sport trophy for its coverage of England's exit from Euro 2004. It was recognised for its "groundbreaking" use of animation. Bafta's Grant Dean, chair of Bafta's Interactive Entertainment committee, said all the entrants had been of "outstanding quality" and that judging had been "enormously difficult". "Without a doubt, 2005 has been a landmark year for the Bafta Interactive Awards," he added.
 
 "Many of the top awards this year have gone to the companies we most commonly associate with traditional entertainment, showing how the gap between new media, film and television is closing."
 
 Awards were given out in 12 different categories, including interactive TV, film, music, design, as well as technical and social innovation, at a London ceremony. The top music award was given to SSEYO miniMIXA, a mobile music sequencer designed to let people write, edit and share compositions. Warner Bros was given two prizes for its "inspiring" efforts in film and DVD interactivity. The Chaplin Collection beat Oasis, Really Bend It Like Beckham, Shaun of the Dead and The Day Today in the DVD category, and Trauma won best film. Elsewhere, fashionista and clothes designer Alexander McQueen took the accolade for the best-designed website. The awards have been running since 1997, but in 2002 the British Academy of Film and Television decided to split them into separate games and interactive ceremonies. On Tuesday Half-Life 2 dominated the games prizes. It collected six Baftas, including best game and best online game.
llama3.2:1b:
The BBC and National Theatre led various awards at this year's Interactive Bafta awards.

National Theatre won for "Stagework" website and factual site.
BBC won three awards: 
- Best online entertainment for the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy Adventure Game
- Top interactive TV prize for Spooks Interactive
- Best news and sport trophy for its coverage of England's exit from Euro 2004

Bafta awarded a range of prizes, including interactive TV, film, music, design, technical innovation, and social innovation.

The top awards in these categories went to companies associated with traditional entertainment.
llama3.2:3b: The BBC won three Interactive Bafta awards, including best online entertainment for its Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy Adventure Game, while the National Theatre took home two awards for its Stagework website. Other winners included Spooks Interactive for best interactive TV, BBC Sport Interactive for best news and sport, and SSEYO miniMIXA for top music award.
gemma2:2b: The BBC and National Theatre won multiple awards at this year's Interactive BAFTAs for their digital content.  The awards recognized outstanding work in various categories including interactive TV, film, music, design, as well as technical and social innovation. Top awards went to the BBC (Hitchhiker's Guide Adventure Game) and Spooks Interactive (best interactive TV).
qwen2.5:0.5b: BBC and National Theatre win Bafta awards at Interactive Bafta competition. The BBC picked up three awards in Interactive Bafta category, including the best online entertainment for the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy Adventure Game. National Theatre won one award: the best interactive TV prize. The annual BAFTA Awards recognize the best digital media. The Bafta Interactive Entertainment committee said all entrants had been of "outstanding quality" and that judging was "enormously difficult". The top awards this year have gone to companies we associate with traditional entertainment, such as BBC, National Theatre, Warner Bros, etc.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The BBC and National Theatre win Interactive Bafta awards for their digital media projects; multiple companies recognized for innovative use of animation in news coverage; traditional entertainment vs new media debate highlighted; technology and design categories also recognized.
qwen2.5:3b: The BBC and National Theatre led this year's Interactive BAFTA awards, with the former winning best learning site for Stagework and three other awards, including best online entertainment (Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy Adventure Game). The BBC also won the best interactive TV prize for Spooks Interactive. BBC Sport Interactive took home the best news and sport award for its Euro 2004 coverage. The ceremony recognized companies traditionally associated with traditional media for their innovative digital work, such as Warner Bros' film and DVD interactivity. Alexander McQueen's website design was also praised. Half-Life 2 dominated the games category with six BAFTAs.

The BBC and the National Theatre were crowned champions at this year's Interactive Bafta awards. Stagework won the prize for best learning as well as a top factual site. The BBC collected three awards, including best online entertainment for *Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy* Adventure Game. Spooks Interactive secured the best interactive TV prize.  

In other categories, Warner Bros. took home two prizes for its inspiring efforts in film and interactivity. The Chaplin Collection led in the DVD category with Trauma winning best film. Alexander McQueen was recognized for his design software, and the BBC Sport Interactive won the best news and sport trophy.

The 2005 year marked a significant milestone for the Interactive Entertainment committee as they celebrated its 18th anniversary. The ceremony highlighted how the gap between traditional entertainment and new media is narrowing.
tinyllama:1.1b: The BBC and National Theatre's Stagework website won three Bafta awards at this year's Interactive Bafta gala ceremony, taking home the best learning site award. The Awards recognise the best in digital media and marked a departure from the traditional entertainment categories that had dominated them since 1997. In addition, spooks Interactive took the best interactive TV prize for its coverage of England's Euro 2004 exit, while BBC Sport Interactive also won the news category with its use of animation in the coverage. The awards were held at London's Old Billingsgate Market on January 7th and saw a diverse mix of categories with 12 different winners.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
BBC's National Theatre has won three BAFTA Awards this year in various categories, including best online entertainment for its interactive Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy Adventure Game. They also picked up a prize for best learning from Interactive Bafta Awards. Spooks Interactive and CBBC Newsround also earned their share of accolades with two awards each. The National Theatre's Stagework website won the award for best factual site, demonstrating its exceptional interactive capabilities. BBC Sport Interactive's accomplishments were recognized in the sports category, including a win in the Best Online Entertainment category. The judges found the entrants’ content to be of "groundbreaking quality" and outstanding innovation, which made it difficult for them to award more than one prize. 

The awards ceremony took place at London’s prestigious Royal Opera House on November 30th, honoring the best in digital media achievements throughout the year. The top music award went to SSEYO miniMIXA, a mobile music sequencer designed to enhance creativity and collaboration within the industry. Warner Bros, which had been nominated for two other awards, won an additional prize for its "inspiring" efforts in film and DVD interactivity. The Chaplin Collection took home the award for best film and also won the Fashionista Designer of the Year Award. Alexander McQueen's fashion design firm Alexander McQueen was recognized with a special prize for the best-designed website, along with Trauma for their efforts in creating "inspiring" films.

SSEYO miniMIXA won the top music award, while Warner Bros was recognized for its interactive DVD projects. The website of fashion designer Alexander McQueen received praise for its design. The annual ceremony celebrated digital media and saw many traditional entertainment companies winning awards, showing how the gap between new media, film and television is closing. The awards have been running since 1997 but were split into separate games and interactive ceremonies in 2002. On Tuesday Half-Life  2 dominated the game prizes, with six awards for best game and best online game.

Other winners included Spooks Interactive winning best interactive TV and Warner Bros receiving two technical and social innovation awards for their work in film and DVD interactivity. Alexander McQueen's website was also awarded best designed website. The British Academy of Film and Television split the awards into separate games and interactive ceremonies in 2002.
